messageBody:
hyysguyang wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "J. B.
> Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> >
> > That's true, but if the code for reverse() is /never/ going to change,
> > then the duplication is better than the over-designed generic solution.
> > I would be very surprised, though, if reverse() is /never/ going to
> > change, and that 'Tdd is a software...' is the only string you'll ever
> > want to reverse. If that were the case, why even write the reverse()
> > method? Why not just put the reversed string in a constant?
>
> True, We must make a balance.Now I think I should stop work when
> return a constant.

This is the greatest lesson I learned from TDD: when the current design
passes all the tests, then stop writing code. If you believe the design
is not complex enough, then you should be able to imagine a test that
creates the need for that complexity. If you can't imagine such a test,
then the design is already complex enough.

Take care.
